Award.AwardTitle: Mechanistic Study of Cellulosome Through Reprogramming Its Assembly

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264708
Guo, Jiantao

This research seeks to study the self-assembly process of cellulosomes, a group of natural protein complexes secreted by microorganisms for the highly efficient degradation of plant cell walls into fermentable sugars. A cellulosome consists of a core scaffoldin protein of structural function and several hydrolytic proteins of catalytic function. Assembly of the cellulosome occurs via interactions between cohesin domains of the scaffoldin protein and matching dockerin domains of catalytic modules. Due to the non-discriminatory nature of cohesin-dockerin recognition in a single microorganism, the assembled cellulosomes have diverse structural and molecular composition. The proposed research seeks to achieve regio- and stoichiometric controlled assembly of designer cellulosomes through engineering orthogonal cohesin-dockerin protein pairs with minimal crosstalking recognition. The engineered cohesin domains with altered specificity will be assembled at pre-arranged positions to form recombinant scaffoldin protein, which enables templated attachment of catalytic modules through matching dockerin domains to form designer cellulosomes. Their structure-activity relationships will be investigated.

The proposed research is expected to lead to synthetic cellulosomes that can outperform their natural counterparts in the process of plant cellulosic material degradation. It will contribute to the generation of biomass-derived feedstocks for biofuel and bioenergy production, which has potential to resolve many long-term economic and environmental concerns. Furthermore, a deeper understanding of the speed and precision of cellulosome self-assembly could lead to new strategies for the synthesis of self-assembled protein complexes with broad impact on the fields of biocatalysis, metabolic engineering, synthetic biology, and nanosciences.
The proposed research represents an outstanding training opportunity for students at all levels of development. Students will be exposed in depth to a large array of research problems in chemistry and biology at the University of Nebraska. Some specific outreach activities include development of a summer research program for undergraduate students from four-year colleges and of chemistry lab kits for high school students. These activities will attract college and high school students, including specifically women and underrepresented students, to pursue studies and academic careers in STEM areas.

This project is jointly funded by the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering Program of the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division, by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology, and by the Office of the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellulosome participates in essential steps in nature’s carbon cycle through a highly efficient degradation of plant cellulosic materials (Figure 1).  The proposed project project seeks to study the self-assembly process of cellulosome and to understand the synergistic action among cellulosomal enzymes.  Such fundamental studies are expected to yield synthetic cellulosomes that can outperform their natural counterparts in the process of plant cellulosic material degradation In the future.  This has attractive promise to be applied as valuable tools to generate biomass-derived feedstocks for biofuel and bioenergy production, which has potential to resolve many long-term economic and environmental concerns.  Furthermore, a deeper understanding of the speed and precision of cellulosome self-assembly could lead to new strategies for the synthesis of self-assembled protein complexes that have broader impact on the fields of biocatalysis, metabolic engineering, synthetic biology, and nanosciences.

Due to the indiscriminatory nature of cohesin-dockerin interaction within a single microorganism species, the assembled cellulosomes have diverse molecular compositions and structures, which correspond to nonhomogeneous catalytic activities for cellulosic material degradation and present a challenge to the study of cellulosome.  Our approach to the study and manipulation of cellulosome depends on the generation of orthogonal cohesin-dockerin pairs with minimal crosstalking interaction, which can be applied to the regio- and stoichiometric controlled attachment of catalytic modules to achieve the assembly of synthetic cellulosomes with pre-defined molecular structure and catalytic property (Figure 2).  In addition to facilitating the study of synergistic action among cellulosomal enzymes, this approach will enable directed evolution of cellulosome in order to realize its full potential in the degradation of plant cellulosic material in the future.

In order to generate orthogonal cohesin-dockerin pairs, we successfully explored a structure-guided, semi-rational protein directed evolution approach to generate orthogonal cohesin-dockerin protein pairs (Figure 3).  To the best of our knowledge, our negative selection method is the first example of applying URA3/5-FOA selection in a bacterial two-hybrid system.  We subsequently generated a dockerin mutant library (mutations in Ser11, Thr12, Ser45, and Thr46), a cohesin mutant library (mutations in Asn37, Asp39, Gly123, and Ala125; Figure 4), and conducted the aforementioned selection.  We successfully identified two orthogonal cohesin-dockerin pairs, Coh1-Doc1 and Coh2-Doc2.  Based on the measurement of dissociation constant, the two evolved pairs showed desirable properties of interaction.  We also designed a fluorescence-based assay (Figure 5) to demonstrate our ability to control the assembly of cellulosomal protein complex.  During the study, we discovered an unexpected but interesting self-cleavage of dockerin fusion proteins.  While the protein cleavage problem delayed our work on the proposed assembly of cellulosomal protein complex, it represents an interesting observation that may lead to new discoveries.  We are currently seeking to solve this mystery.  To illustrate that our selection system can be generalized to evolve other orthogonal protein pairs, we also examined the engineering of orthogonal barnase-barstar pair, which is often used as a model system for the study of protein interaction, folding, and stability.  Indeed, we were able to identify multiple protein pairs from the selection.

The educational component of the project focused on integrating research and education activities, promoting students’ interests in science in general and biocatalysis and biomolecular engineering in specific, and increasing underrepresented groups’ participation in science.  During the project period, we have provided training and research opportunities for four undergraduate students, four graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers.  Besides participating in the proposed research project, they were also exposed in depth to a large array of research problems in chemistry and biology that are ongoing in PI’s lab as well as in other laboratories at the University of Nebraska.  We were glad that we were able to attract a number of women and underrepresented students to this research project.  In the long term, such efforts will encourage women and underrepresented students to pursue studies and academic careers in STEM areas.

As an outreach effort, PI (Guo), co-PI (Niu), and two other University of Nebraska faculty members organized and mentored the first undergraduate iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machine) team from the State of Nebraska.  The team consisted six undergraduate students from three different departments.  They conducted their research in PI’s lab during summer 2016 and successfully completed a research project that focused on reducing nitrate concentration in waterways of Nebraska.  The students discussed their research with local biotechnology companies and gave presentations to students at local high schools.  They also conducted a special science exhibition, Building with Biology, in the Nebraska State Museum.  They won the team volunteer of the year award from the Nebraska State Museum.
